Article Title: WFH status shouldn’t tilt balance in custody battle: SC
Article Text:
Supreme Court of India



NEW DELHI: Noting that both partners in a marriage must work to meet individual as well as family needs and aspirations, which include securing good education for their wards, SC has said a child custody dispute between working parents cannot be decided in favour of one of them on the criterion that they work from home. A bench of Justices Manoj Misra and Ujjal Bhuyan remarked that it could not be said that the interests of the child would be better served by the parent who worked from home, than the other who went to office daily.“It is not in dispute that both parents are working parents and, therefore, it is expected that they cannot always be physically with their children. But this cannot be a ground to place the custody of the child with the one who may be temporarily working from home because it is a matter of common knowledge that to meet individual as well as family aspirations, married couples have to work to build a proper home, and most importantly, to secure better education for their ward. .. We, therefore, do not subscribe to the view that if one parent is working from home and the other is not (i.e., has to visit his office for work) then it has to be inferred that child’s interest would be better served if he is placed in the custody of one who does not go to office for work,” the bench said.SC was hearing a custody dispute over a five-year-old boy in NCR. The couple has two children — a boy and a girl, with the former living with the father and the girl with the mother.SC interacted with the minor who wanted the company of his sister but was not willing to leave his father.“What is important is that from our interactions we noticed he was not willing to part company of his father. We also took notice of the fact that his father has a few elder members at home, including grandfather, who are giving company to the child. In such circumstances, having regard to thefact that the male child is now above five years old and hecontinues to be in the same school where he was studying earlier, and he has no issues with his own father and is not willing to part company of his father, an interference with the order passed by HC is not required, particularly in view of the fact that the appellant (mother) has visitation rights as directed earlier by this court ,” the court said.HC, while granting custody of the child to the father, had mentioned he was working from home. SC’s clarification came with this in mind.
Article Summary: SC was hearing a custody dispute over a five-year-old boy in NCR. The couple has two children — a boy and a girl, with the former living with the father and the girl with the mother. SC interacted with the minor who wanted the company of his sister but was not willing to leave his father.

Article Title: Niti panel backs licences, permits for perpetuity
Article Text:
File photo

NEW DELHI: Govt policy think tank Niti Aayog has recommended that licences, permits and NOCs should have perpetual validity, except in cases where renewal is required for reasons of national security, serious harm to public safety, human health, environment, or in public interest, among a series of measures to ensure a “trust-based regulatory framework”.A panel headed by Niti Aayog member Rajiv Gauba has also suggested that inspections be carried out by accredited third parties selected through computer-assisted randomised processes based on risk assessment. Officials said that by ensuring predictability, proportionality and fairness, such a system reduces enforcement burden, promotes innovation and sustains confidence, improving governance outcomes. The suggestions have been sent to ministries and departments.The panel has also suggested that even in cases of renewal of licences, permits and NOCs for reasons such as national security and serious harm to public safety or health, the validity period may be for five or 10 years. It has said that licencing and compliance requirements must be proportionate and graded by risk, and there should be no requirement of prior approvals for licences, permits and NOCs in ordinary cases.“Any activity not explicitly prohibited under the law shall be exempted from prior permission,” the think tank said. It has also said registration may be required for maintenance of database or other important purposes, but these must not be subject to approval or rejection. Self-registration based on minimal documentation shall be the norm, it has said.In its bid to eliminate ‘inspector raj’, Niti Aayog has said that inspections by accredited third parties should be the norm and departments must put the selection and periodic performance assessment criteria for third parties in place. “Inspection by govt officers will be only when necessary and through well-defined SOPs,” it said.With focus on decriminalising offences, Niti Aayog has told ministries that minor, procedural and technical offences should be decriminalised and criminal offences should be only for serious offences. It has also suggested the need to have interoperability at ministry level so that information once submitted need not be fed to the system again.
Article Summary: Policy think tank Niti Aayog has recommended that licences, permits and NOCs should have perpetual validity. Panel has also suggested that inspections be carried out by accredited third parties. Officials said that by ensuring predictability, proportionality and fairness, such a system reduces enforcement burden and promotes innovation.

Article Title: India-Russia ties: Putin to begin visit today with PM Modi’s private dinner; trade in focus
Article Text:
Putin to start India visit with pvt dinner hosted by PM Modi



Russia Confirms Su-57 Fighter Jets, S-400 Deal On Agenda Ahead of Vladimir Putin’s India Visit

NEW DELHI: Russian President Vladimir Putin will begin his first visit to India in four years with a private dinner hosted by PM Narendra Modi Thursday. The two will discuss ways to shore up the special and privileged strategic partnership with a focus on economic ties, while exchanging views on key global and regional issues. The PM is expected to reiterate India’s position seeking early end to the Russia-Ukraine war and a return to dialogue and diplomacy. Putin had hosted Modi for a private dinner during the latter’s Russia visit last year for the annual summit.Putin’s main engagements are scheduled for Friday, beginning with a visit to Rajghat, followed by a ceremonial welcome at Rashtrapati Bhavan. The leaders will hold talks at Hyderabad House for the main summit. After lunch with Modi, Putin will participate in India-Russia Business Forum. He will return to Rashtrapati Bhavan, where President Droupadi Murmu will host a banquet in his honour.Putin’s aide Yury Ushakov said a joint statement was expected to be adopted and bilateral documents would be signed across a wide range of areas, including Program for the Development of Strategic Areas of Russian-Indian Economic Cooperation until 2030.Modi last held a bilateral meeting with Putin on the margins of SCO summit this year in Tianjin, and the two have spoken by phone five times in 2024.“This visit... provides an opportunity to discuss the extensive agenda of Russian-Indian relations comprehensively. In addition to the main talks with Narendra Modi, the programme includes a visit to the Russia-India Business Forum and participation in the launch ceremony of the RT TV channel in India,” Ushakov said.He added key aspects of trade and economic cooperation would be discussed. “In 2024, the bilateral trade turnover increased by 12%, up to $63.6 billion. We have many large-scale promising projects in various areas, including industrial cooperation, innovative technologies, transport, peaceful space exploration, mining, healthcare and labour migration progra-mmes,” he said, adding both sides were strengthening cooperation in politics and security, economy and finance, transport and logistics, science and technology, education and culture. Putin is expected to depart around 9.30 pm Friday.
Article Summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin will begin his first visit to India in four years with a private dinner hosted by PM Narendra Modi. The two will discuss ways to shore up the special and privileged strategic partnership with a focus on economic ties. Putin’s aide Yury Ushakov said a joint statement was expected to be adopted and bilateral documents would be signed.

What does this mean for migration policy?





The bottom line









The irony is sharp. For years, British universities depended on international students to keep their books balanced and their campuses global. Now many of those same institutions are quietly shutting their doors to two of their biggest applicant pools. The sector insists this is about compliance, not discrimination, but the effect is unmistakable: students from Pakistan and Bangladesh are being blocked, deferred or dropped because universities fear breaching tougher Home Office rules.Here is the full breakdown.Several UK universities have stopped accepting new applications from Pakistan and Bangladesh after tighter Home Office rules made it riskier to sponsor students from countries with high visa refusal rates.The trigger is the overhaul of the Basic Compliance Assessment, the framework universities must meet to retain their student sponsor licence. Under the updated rules, no more than 5 per cent of an institution’s sponsored visa applications can be refused. The previous limit was 10 per cent.Pakistan and Bangladesh now sit well above the new threshold. Their refusal rates — roughly 18 per cent for Pakistan and 22 per cent for Bangladesh in the year to September 2025 — put universities at risk of sanctions, including losing their ability to enrol international students altogether.For many mid-tier and lower-fee institutions, that is an existential threat.Some institutions have reinstated certain programmes for the January intake, but most remain cautious.Why are refusal rates so high?Three major trends have converged:The government has tightened student-visa rules as part of a broader strategy to reduce net migration. Universities now face stricter monitoring of outcomes: refusal rates, enrolment follow-through, and student attendance.There has been a surge in asylum claims lodged by individuals who first entered the UK on a study or work visa. Ministers have warned universities that student routes must not become a “backdoor” to settlement.Some universities rely heavily on education agents to source students. Multiple insiders say poor vetting — particularly in high-volume markets — has led to a mix of strong applicants alongside others with weak documentation or questionable intentions.This combination has pushed refusal rates above the new threshold, putting institutions at risk of non-compliance.For thousands of genuine applicants, the consequences are immediate and painful:Education consultants in the region say the decisions are “heartbreaking” for students who did everything correctly but are caught in the crossfire of institutional risk-management.They also argue that UK universities themselves created the incentives that led to aggressive agent recruitment, weak documentation and fraudulent applications — and are now punishing students for it.The new rules are unforgiving. If a university breaches the 5 per cent refusal cap or other compliance metrics, it can lose its licence to sponsor international students for at least a year.A one-year loss could mean:Officials estimate that at least 22 universities would fail at least one compliance criterion if no corrective action is taken. Five of them could lose their sponsorship rights outright, cutting an estimated 12,000 international students from the system.For lower-fee universities, heavily dependent on international enrolments, even a brief suspension could be fatal.Institutions are now:The result is a cautious and sometimes blunt response: cutting entire markets to protect compliance.The UK government has made it clear that the new rules are intended to restore public confidence in the international student route. Ministers argue that genuine students remain welcome but institutions must take greater responsibility for screening applicants. At the same time, universities warn that the reforms will reshape the sector — reducing diversity, limiting access for students from developing countries, and pushing institutions toward more profitable markets such as China and the Gulf. The Home Office maintains that it “strongly values” international students but insists that only genuine applicants should come to the UK.The freeze on recruitment from Pakistan and Bangladesh is not a political statement by universities. It is a defensive manoeuvre forced by tougher immigration rules, high refusal rates and the fear of losing the right to sponsor students altogether. But regardless of the intention, the impact is immediate: thousands of South Asian students now find their UK education plans derailed, delayed or dropped — not because of their merit, but because the system around them changed overnight.
Article Summary: Several UK universities have stopped accepting new applications from Pakistan and Bangladesh after tighter Home Office rules. The trigger is the overhaul of the Basic Compliance Assessment, the framework universities must meet to retain their student sponsor licence. Under the updated rules, no more than 5 per cent of an institution’s sponsored visa applications can be refused.

Article Title: 'Something badly wrong with H-1B': Former visa officer says he interviewed average college graduates in India
Article Text:
'Unfair to compare Chinese or Indian student with American student'

Donald Trump's Stricter H-1B Visa Rule Hits Indian Talent, Background Check Screening Expanded





Researcher Simon Hankinson who worked as a visa officer in India opened up about his experience of interviewing for H-1B visa program 25 years ago and said he did not fail to see even at the beginning what was wrong with the program. In an opinion piece for Fox News, Hankinson wrote that something was badly wrong with the program which intended to bring 'specialty' workers to the US. But in reality, even 25 years ago, it was average college graduates that he interviewed for the visa program, he said.Hankinson said it's unfair to compare between a Chinese of an Indian student with an American student as a Chinese or Indian student goes to free or inexpensive schools in their countries, gets a BA, MA or even a PhD with little debt. But in America, students are borrowing thousands of dollars to get to the same level. "They can’t take jobs at the same low salaries their H-1B competitors can," Hankinson said."Amazon got over 10,000 approvals for H-1B visas in 2025, in the same year as they announced cuts of over 30,000 jobs. Was any effort made to retrain or re-assign Americans? Many other large US companies follow the same pattern: hire abroad, fire at home."Hankinson also said that US companies do not need a lot of specialty workers. "The truth is, the number of real "specialty" workers that even big American companies really need should fit in a bus, not a stadium. And they should be willing to pay a high premium for them," he wrote."If AI firms are really willing to pay up to a hundred million dollars in signing bonuses for top talent, they will be willing to pay high salaries to get a few essential foreign workers. Some in Washington want to increase visas for foreign workers. Some even believe that Americans should have to compete for their jobs with the whole world. I don’t," he wrote.In his recent H-1B report for the Heritage Foundation, Hankinson cited the example of Indian politician Kandi Srinivas Reddy, who allegedly used several shell companies to submit multiple H-1B petitions for the same workers. In the 2020 lottery, Reddy reportedly submitted more than 3000 entries, Hankinson wrote, pointing out the abuse of the system that went on for a long time.
Article Summary: Researcher Simon Hankinson who worked as a visa officer in India opened up about his experience of interviewing for H-1B visa program 25 years ago. Hankinson said it's unfair to compare between a Chinese of an Indian student with an American student.

Article Title: IndiGo crisis: CEO admits operational failures in letter to staff; asserts restoring punctuality is ‘immediate goal’
Article Text:
Representative image

IndiGo Crisis: Inside Pilot Shortage, Rule Change and Winter Delays Behind Over 200 Cancellations

IndiGo CEO Pieter Elbers has written to employees acknowledging the severe disruptions that have hit the airline in recent days, conceding that IndiGo “could not live up to the promise” of providing a good travel experience to passengers.The carrier has seen more than 300 flight cancellations on Thursday alone, with scores of services delayed as operational challenges mounted.In the internal message, Elbers said the past few days had been “difficult for many of our IndiGo customers and colleagues”, noting that the airline serves close to 3.8 lakh customers daily but had failed to meet expectations.“We could not live up to that promise these past days and we have publicly apologised for that,” he said.Elbers attributed the crisis to a mix of “minor technology glitches, schedule changes, adverse weather conditions, heightened congestion in the aviation ecosystem, and the implementation of the newly released FDTL norms”, which “compounded negatively to create a cascading impact on our operations”.He expressed gratitude to pilots, cabin crew, engineers, OCC, customer support, digital teams and airport staff who have been working “tirelessly to manage the situation, minimise the impact, and restore stability as quickly as possible”.As per PTI, IndiGo’s on-time performance had plunged to 19.7 per cent on December 3, underlining the scale of the disruption.Elbers told staff that given the size and complexity of IndiGo’s network, disruptions “grow large immediately” and require interventions at multiple levels. “Our immediate goal is to normalise our operations and bring punctuality back on track in the coming days, which is not an easy target,” he wrote.The DGCA has summoned IndiGo’s senior management to explain the unprecedented nationwide disruptions and present a corrective plan.The airline has already initiated “calibrated adjustments” to its schedules for the next 48 hours to stabilise operations, according to its official statement.Elbers, in his letter, urged employees to come together as one team, recalling how IndiGo recently completed the upgrade of 200 A320 aircraft within 24 hours. “I am confident we all can deal with this challenge too… Together, as one team, we will overcome this challenge and emerge even stronger,” he said.
Article Summary: IndiGo CEO Pieter Elbers has written to employees acknowledging the severe disruptions that have hit the airline in recent days. The carrier has seen more than 300 flight cancellations on Thursday alone. Elbers attributed the crisis to a mix of “minor technology glitches, schedule changes, adverse weather conditions, heightened congestion in the aviation ecosystem, and the implementation of the newly released FDTL norms”

Article Title: Putin’s India visit: Trade in focus as New Delhi looks to reduce deficit; exports of pharma, agriculture likely to get a push
Article Text:
File photo: PM Modi with Russian President Vladimir Putin (Picture credit: ANI)

Putin Plans Big India Reset With More Indian Goods, Deep Strategic Defence Ties In Talks With Modi

Strengthening economic cooperation, boosting exports





Key agreements and new areas of collaboration

Deepening people-to-people ties

Russian President Vladimir Putin’s visit to India is likely to deliver a significant push to economic cooperation, with government sources indicating that New Delhi is looking to narrow its trade deficit and secure deeper market access for Indian goods.President Putin is arriving with a large business delegation, signalling what officials describe as a strong commercial intent behind the trip.Government sources told TOI that the visit is expected to go a long way in strengthening economic co-operation, with President Putin travelling alongside a large delegation of business representatives.India expects progress in reducing the significant trade deficit with Russia, and multiple avenues are being explored to increase Indian exports. These include pharmaceuticals, automobiles, and agricultural goods such as marine products.Officials said improved export access would help Indian businesses secure a bigger market in Russia. This is also expected to support job creation and enhance the well-being of India’s farmers by widening opportunities for agricultural shipments.Multiple agreements and MoUs are expected during the visit in areas such as shipping, healthcare, fertilisers and connectivity, according to government sources.Broader cooperation is also likely in people-to-people engagement, mobility partnerships, cultural exchanges and scientific collaboration.The two sides are also preparing for the signing of key bilateral documents during Friday’s summit, including a long-term roadmap for economic cooperation until 2030.President Putin is further scheduled to address the India–Russia Business Forum, where both governments expect to energise private-sector partnerships and attract new investments.Beyond economic and trade outcomes, government sources said the visit will also focus on enhancing societal ties.This includes mobility arrangements, cultural cooperation and scientific partnerships, giving the relationship greater depth beyond traditional areas such as defence and energy.
Article Summary: Vladimir Putin’s visit to India is likely to deliver a significant push to economic cooperation. New Delhi is looking to narrow its trade deficit and secure deeper market access for Indian goods. Multiple agreements and MoUs are expected in areas such as shipping, healthcare, fertilisers and connectivity. Broader cooperation is also likely in people-to-people engagement, mobility partnerships, cultural exchanges and scientific collaboration.

Article Title: Real Story Behind Dhurandhar Movie: 'Dhurandhar' walks into Karachi's 'Wild West': The real story of Lyari gang war
Article Text:
Major Mohit Sharma’s Brother Explains Why Family Seeks Stay On 'Dhurandhar' Release!

Lyari: From labour colony to PPP stronghold





Early underworld structures: From hashish traders to street violence





Rise of Rehman Dakait and the Peoples’ Aman Committee





Feuds, betrayal and the making of Uzair Baloch





Parallel governance, ‘parchi’ systems and water mafias





Several informal systems operated during this period:

The ‘Parchi’ System: Residents, businesses and even small schools were required to obtain a stamped permission slip or parchi from PAC offices to build, renovate, operate stalls or open new ventures. What looked like a routine approval process effectively served as taxation, a tool of surveillance and a means to regulate economic activity.

Water and Tanker Control: Amid persistent water shortages across Karachi, PAC factions captured key pipeline points and operated illegal hydrants. Water was sold through tankers at inflated rates, turning a basic utility into one of the most profitable sources of revenue for the gangs. Control over water distribution also gave PAC leverage over entire neighbourhoods.

Welfare Patronage and ‘Robin Hood’ Politics: A share of illicit earnings was used to sponsor madrassas, support religious events, organise football tournaments, fund community funerals and assist poor families. This welfare strategy deepened PAC’s influence and aligned it with PPP’s political base, reinforcing the perception of gang leaders as protectors rather than mere criminals.

PPP, the Bhuttos and the contested 'protector' narrative





A factual account of the events surrounding Benazir’s return and death underscores this point:

Karsaz bombing (18 October 2007): Benazir was in an open truck surrounded by PPP volunteers, not in a car. Her protection was largely handled by party workers and an informal crowd, not gang networks.

Assassination in Rawalpindi December, 27, 2007: At the time she was targeted, she was travelling in a white Toyota Land Cruiser driven by Javed Rehman, a trained PPP driver, not Rehman Dakait. No credible evidence links the gangster to her security detail.

Operations, encounters and the death of Rehman Dakait





Uzair Baloch, Baba Ladla and the peak of the Lyari Gang War





Operation Lyari 2012: Siege, failure and civilian cost





Taliban militancy and the Karachi Operation





Assassination of Chaudhry Aslam and the killing of Baba Ladla





Arrest, espionage charges and trials of Uzair Baloch





Political fallout and PPP’s distancing





Post-war Lyari: Quiet streets, unresolved questions









NEW DELHI: Karachi’s Lyari has long been associated with a dual identity. To its residents, it is the “mother of Karachi” – one of the city’s oldest settlements powered by dockworkers, truck drivers, boxers and footballers. To the rest of Pakistan, especially through the 1990s and 2000s, it came to signify something very different: a “mini Brazil” of football-obsessed alleys, heavily armed gangs, and extortion rackets, long branded as Karachi’s “wild west.”It is this layered, contradictory Lyari that Aditya Dhar’s recent 'Dhurandhar' turns into cinema. The film revolves around characters that seem to be inspired by gangster Rehman Dakait, police officer Chaudhry Aslam and a shadowy military-intelligence player resembling Ilyas Kashmiri (fictionalised as Major Iqbal). Alongside Pakistani security figures, the narrative hints at a foreign intelligence angle featuring an unnamed “Indian spy chief” — a character with echoes of a former top security official who, in real life, has been involved in covert roles in regional conflicts in Pakistan. These references remain ambiguous on screen, but they mirror real allegations that have circulated for years through local press conferences, dossiers and counterclaims on both sides of the border.Reacting to the controversy around Dhurandhar and the a case file in Delhi high court, Major Mohit Sharma’s brother, Madhur Sharma, said the petition was filed due to ongoing speculation that the film was inspired by the Ashok Chakra awardee’s life without any transparency from the makers. Madhur clarified that the family is not opposed to a film based on Major Sharma, but objected to the possibility of using his story without consent. “We would be proud if a film is made on him. Even in 2021, a film was announced and we supported the producers. He has left a legacy, and it should live on,” he said. The family maintains that they are only seeking clarity and dignity for the officer: “There is no benefit the parents are looking for… If the film is based on him, just say, ‘Sorry ma’am, we didn’t inform you.’ If not, say the hype is untrue.”The Delhi high court heard the plea filed by Major Sharma’s parents seeking a review before the film’s release. While the court did not stay the December 5 release of Dhurandhar, it acknowledged the legitimacy of the family’s concerns regarding similarities to a real-life officer without consent. The court referred the matter to the Central Board of Film Certification (CBFC) for examination, noting the need for regulatory scrutiny before the film proceeds.Following the controversy, director Aditya Dhar issued a clarification on X addressed to the family. He wrote: “Hi, sir - our film Dhurandhar is not based on the life of braveheart Major Mohit Sharma AC(P) SM. This is an official clarification. I assure you, if we do make a biopic on Mohit sir in the future, we will do it with full consent and in complete consultation with the family, and in a way that truly honors his sacrifice for the nation and the legacy it has left for all of us. Jai Hind.”This blurred mix of fact, rumour and state narrative reflects Lyari’s history itself. For more than six decades, the neighbourhood has moved on two parallel tracks. One is a working-class community that powered Karachi’s docks, produced champion boxers and footballers, and remained a loyal base of the Pakistan People's Party ( PPP ). The other is a network of gangs and protection rackets that emerged from the hashish trade of the 1960s and later expanded into narcotics trafficking, extortion, land capture and control of water tankers.Successive governments, including PPP administrations, did not simply fight these groups; at various points they bargained with them, funded them or turned a blind eye. Leaders like Rehman Dakait, and later Uzair Baloch, acted not only as crime bosses but as political intermediaries who ran parallel governance under the banner of the Peoples’ Aman Committee (PAC), often brandishing PPP flags at their offices. As Taliban networks poured into Karachi in the 2000s and regional intelligence rivalries spilled into the city, Lyari’s gangs were no longer seen merely as enforcers protecting a vote bank — they were gradually treated as potential pieces in a wider security chessboard.With Dhurandhar reigniting attention, this story revisits how Lyari transformed from a labour colony to PPP stronghold to a battleground shaped by gang wars, state patronage, counter-terror operations and allegations of espionage. What emerges is not simply the tale of feared men, but the story of a neighbourhood where poverty, politics and competing security agendas turned everyday life into a prolonged and violent conflict.a long, violent war.Lyari is among the oldest continuously inhabited parts of Karachi and holds a foundational place in the city’s history. Long before Karachi became Pakistan’s financial hub, Lyari evolved as a working-class settlement dominated by Baloch communities who migrated from coastal and interior regions in search of livelihoods. During the 18th and 19th centuries, as the port emerged as the centre of colonial trade, Baloch labourers became indispensable to loading cargo, building roads and supporting maritime activities. This early dependence on manual workers gradually transformed Lyari into a labour colony closely interlinked with Karachi’s industrial and infrastructural growth.Despite its importance in sustaining the city’s economy, the locality remained neglected in terms of urban development. Narrow lanes, dense housing clusters, unreliable utilities and limited state services came to define its daily reality. Yet, Lyari’s social fabric remained strong: sports, community centres and local cultural traditions created a sense of belonging that distinguished it from other Karachi neighbourhoods.In politics, Lyari’s identity further crystallised with the rise of the Pakistan People's Party. Since the 1970s, the PPP’s populist messaging—centred on economic justice and empowerment of marginalised groups—found deep resonance in Lyari. During decades of shifting political power in Karachi, the locality consistently returned PPP candidates to provincial and national assemblies. This loyalty turned Lyari into the party’s most dependable urban stronghold, a constituency where electoral victories were seldom in doubt.Over time, however, this relationship between Lyari and the PPP took a complex turn. As Karachi’s security landscape deteriorated in the 1980s and 1990s, the party increasingly relied on local strongmen, community leaders and later armed groups to maintain influence and protect its vote bank. Patronage networks developed, blurring the lines between politics, street authority and organised crime. What began as a working-class community with a vibrant political identity would eventually become the focal point of Karachi’s most violent gang conflict—one in which loyalty, power and criminality became deeply entangled.The roots of the Lyari gang war go back to the 1960s, when the area emerged as a key node in the local hashish trade. According to both journalistic and academic accounts, early figures like Dad Muhammad (“Dadal”) and his brother Sheru moved into the hashish business in the mid-1960s, challenging the dominance of an older drug boss known as “Kala Nag”.Kala Nag was eventually killed in what was officially described as a police encounter, and the hashish economy fragmented into rival factions. Violence at this stage largely revolved around knives and small arms, with public killings used to send messages and enforce territorial control.In the 1990s, a more educated generation of criminals appeared. One of the most prominent was Iqbal, known locally as “Babu Dacoit”, who reportedly held a Master’s degree in physics. Operating across a wider network, he ran drugs and other rackets while remaining largely beyond the reach of the police. His later arrest, when he was already paralysed, symbolised a shift from small-scale street crime to more organised, networked operations.A major shift in Lyari’s politics and crime landscape came with the ascent of Sardar Abdul Rehman Baloch, widely known as Rehman Dakait. Born into a family already linked to smuggling networks, Rehman entered the criminal world at a young age. By the mid-1990s, he had developed a reputation for extreme violence, with local accounts even alleging that he murdered his own mother during a domestic dispute—an unverified but persistent story that reinforced his notoriety.By the early 2000s, Rehman had consolidated control over large parts of Lyari’s illicit economy, including drug trafficking, extortion and gambling rackets. Yet, he also cultivated an image as a benefactor. Oral histories, media reporting and academic studies describe how he funded small clinics, madrassas, football tournaments, neighbourhood parks and schools, using criminal proceeds to build patronage. This dual identity—provider and predator—helped him secure legitimacy among segments of the local population who felt abandoned by the state.Rehman’s rise coincided with Lyari’s continued loyalty to the PPP. As political competition intensified in Karachi, PPP leaders increasingly saw strategic value in a local armed actor who could protect the party’s dominance and mobilise votes. Political alignment, according to multiple accounts, allowed Rehman to operate with greater impunity and helped formalise gang influence under a new name: the Peoples’ Aman Committee (PAC).Formed around 2008, the PAC presented itself as a community “peace” organisation but functioned as an institutionalised version of Rehman’s operations. It opened offices, appointed local commanders, mediated disputes, collected protection money and distributed welfare. In a context of chronic state neglect, many residents began to rely on the PAC as a parallel administration, making it one of the most powerful non-state authorities Karachi had ever seen.The roots of Lyari’s modern gang war lie in an older conflict shaped by ransom kidnappings, shifting alliances and internal betrayals. In the 1980s and 1990s, parts of Lyari’s criminal economy were dominated by a figure known as Haji Lalu, with another notorious operator, Dadal, working as one of his trusted aides. Disputes over ransom money extorted from wealthy businessmen gradually fractured this relationship. The split laid the foundation for two rival blocs: one centred on Lalu and his son, Arshad Pappu, and the other aligned with Dadal’s family, including his son, Rehman Dakait.The rivalry intensified through the 1990s. Dadal’s murder—widely believed to have been carried out by a competing gang—created a vacuum that Rehman moved to fill, initially with Lalu’s support. But a later dispute over a substantial ransom sum allegedly taken behind Rehman’s back marked the end of that partnership. The fallout turned the former allies into adversaries, cementing a bitter feud between Rehman’s camp and that of Haji Lalu and Arshad Pappu.A separate event subsequently brought an important new actor onto the scene: Uzair Jan Baloch, the son of a transport businessman, Faiz Muhammad, known locally as Mama Faizu. According to both police records and local accounts, Faizu was kidnapped and killed in 2003 by men linked to Arshad Pappu. Uzair initially attempted to seek justice through legal channels but reportedly faced threats and obstruction. Sharing a common enemy in Pappu, he turned instead toward his cousin, Rehman Dakait, joining his organisation.Over the following years, the Rehman–Uzair alliance fought a sustained war against the Pappu–Lalu network. What began as a dispute over illicit profits evolved into a violent cycle of killings, reprisals and territorial battles. By the mid-2000s, the feud had escalated into one of the deadliest urban conflicts in Karachi, with casualties running into the hundreds and paving the way for a new era of militarised gang politics.With the rise of Rehman Dakait and, later, Uzair Baloch, the Peoples’ Aman Committee (PAC) grew beyond a criminal network and evolved into a parallel governance structure in Lyari. Between roughly 2008 and 2013, researchers describe Lyari as effectively under PAC’s informal administration, with neighbourhood “commanders’’ exercising authority over small jurisdictions. These commanders managed disputes, issued permissions and collected funds in a manner that closely resembled state functions.These overlapping spheres blurred boundaries between state actors and non-state power. PAC offices routinely displayed both their own banners and PPP flags, while police operations in Lyari were often delayed, curtailed or influenced by political pressure. For a period, the PAC did not simply challenge state authority—it partially replaced it.Within Lyari, Rehman Dakait was widely viewed as being closely aligned with senior leaders of the Pakistan People's Party (PPP). Journalistic reporting and local accounts repeatedly describe him as someone who maintained proximity to the Bhutto leadership and attended major PPP political events.A popular narrative in Lyari claims that Rehman “saved” former prime minister Benazir Bhutto during the 18 October 2007 Karsaz attack in Karachi, when two explosions targeted her homecoming procession. In these accounts, Rehman is portrayed as part of an informal security circle that helped her escape following the blast. The story has fuelled his “protector” image and contributed to his Robin Hood-style mystique.However, despite the narrative’s frequency in oral history, there is no independent, verifiable evidence confirming that Rehman personally rescued Benazir or served as her driver or official security guard at any point. What is more clearly documented is the broader political relationship: Lyari’s gangs and the PPP operated in a framework of mutual benefit for years, with the party relying on armed control of the constituency and the gangs receiving political space to operate.After the PPP returned to power in 2008, Rehman publicly rebranded himself as Sardar Abdul Rehman Baloch, presenting the Peoples’ Aman Committee as a community organisation rather than a gang body. His growing political visibility, and reported sympathies with certain Baloch nationalist circles, are believed by some analysts and residents to have contributed to his killing in a controversial police “encounter” in 2009.As media scrutiny of Lyari intensified and gang violence spread to other parts of Karachi, state pressure began to mount. At the centre of this response was SSP Chaudhry Aslam Khan, an officer in the Crime Investigation Department (CID) known for aggressive policing tactics. Aslam cultivated a reputation as an “encounter specialist,” targeting both militant groups and organised crime. His public stance against Lyari gangs put him in direct confrontation with Rehman Dakait, who by the mid-2000s had become one of the most influential figures in Karachi’s underworld.Law enforcement records and press reports from the period describe a tense cat-and-mouse dynamic between the two men. Rehman repeatedly evaded capture; in at least two documented incidents, he escaped custody after allegedly bribing police officers. According to local media accounts and later investigations, Rehman paid select CID and jail officials to secure temporary releases or avoid charges, a practice facilitated by weak internal oversight and political protection. These incidents contributed to Aslam’s personal resolve. Journalists covering Karachi’s crime beat recall that Aslam increasingly framed the pursuit of Rehman as a matter of professional and personal credibility for the police force.On 9 August 2009, police announced that Rehman had been killed in a shootout near Steel Town, on Karachi’s outskirts. Officials claimed that Rehman and three accomplices opened fire on police and were killed in retaliatory fire. However, from the outset, rights groups and local residents questioned the official account. Activists, lawyers and researchers later described the killing as a likely extrajudicial execution, consistent with a broader pattern of “encounters” used in Karachi to bypass a slow judicial system and fragile witness protections.With Rehman removed, the gang landscape did not stabilise. Instead, the Peoples’ Aman Committee (PAC), which he had informally led, underwent a leadership transition. Within weeks, Uzair Jan Baloch was positioned as Rehman’s successor, assuming both the criminal networks and the political connections tied to PPP support. Unlike Rehman, whose authority rested heavily on personality and charisma, Uzair’s tenure was marked by greater bureaucratisation—defined commanders, more formalised extortion systems and deeper conflict with the state. This period would set the stage for some of the bloodiest episodes of the Lyari gang war.After Rehman Dakait’s killing in 2009, leadership of the Lyari network did not pass smoothly to a single successor. Uzair Jan Baloch projected himself as the political head of the organisation: educated, relatively well-spoken, and comfortable appearing alongside PPP leaders. His image contrasted sharply with the operational commander Noor Muhammad, better known as “Baba Ladla”, who had a reputation for ruthlessness built over years as an enforcer in neighbourhood turf battles.Initially, the two worked side by side under the Peoples’ Aman Committee (PAC) banner. But disagreements over extortion routes, neighbourhood control and access to political patrons gradually turned into open rivalry. Within Lyari, some commanders gravitated toward Uzair’s political authority and alleged links to provincial leadership; others aligned with Baba Ladla’s street power. This divide transformed PAC from a single entity into competing armed factions.The conflict reached its most infamous moment in March 2013, with the killing of rival gangster Arshad Pappu. According to court filings and media reporting, Pappu and his brother Yasir Arafat were abducted from Karachi’s Defence neighbourhood and taken to Lyari. Both were tortured, killed and later mutilated. Their remains were reportedly burned and dumped—widely interpreted as Uzair’s retaliation for the killing of his father, Faiz Muhammad. Some later accounts, including police dossiers and local testimonies, alleged that gang members kicked or played football with severed heads, turning the murders into a grim public spectacle that circulated in local narratives.By this stage, the greatest toll fell on ordinary residents. Prolonged firefights between splinter factions left neighbourhoods barricaded for days. Homes and small businesses were commandeered as torture rooms or lookout posts. Young men were coerced into gang recruitment, teachers and shopkeepers were forced to pay “taxes,” and ambulance workers trying to retrieve bodies were threatened by both sides. In response, the state increasingly turned to large-scale fires, sieges and heavy weaponry, culminating in the militarised crackdowns that would soon follow.In April–May 2012, the Sindh government initiated one of Karachi’s largest security actions against gang networks, later known as Operation Lyari. The police deployed thousands of personnel, armoured carriers and specialised units with the stated goal of clearing the area and arresting key commanders linked to the Peoples’ Aman Committee (PAC). For the first time, a formal state crackdown directly targeted the network that had operated for years through political patronage and parallel governance.The operation, however, quickly encountered intense resistance. Armed groups used heavy weaponry, including rocket-propelled grenades (RPGs), to attack the advancing police. Several armoured personnel carriers were damaged or destroyed, and police units struggled to push through Lyari’s dense alleyways, where snipers and lookout positions gave gang members a tactical advantage. After several days of fighting, rising casualties, and growing criticism from political circles, the operation stalled. It ended without major arrests and was widely perceived as a failure that exposed both the state’s limitations and PAC’s entrenched power.For residents, the consequences were immediate and severe. Lyari was effectively sealed off for about a week, with restricted movement in and out of the neighbourhood. Power and water supplies were disrupted, markets were shut, and families already living under economic strain faced shortages of food and basic essentials. Humanitarian groups and ambulance services reported being blocked or delayed from providing aid, amid police suspicions that relief efforts could serve as a cover to transport weapons or militants.The failed siege deepened mistrust between civilians, gangs and the state. Many residents had already endured years of coercive “taxes” and violence under PAC rule; the security operation then subjected them to collective punishment, indiscriminate fire and deprivation. Instead of restoring confidence, the crackdown reinforced the perception that both the state and the gangs were willing to sacrifice ordinary people to protect their own interests.Even as Lyari’s gang networks fought prolonged turf wars, Karachi was simultaneously becoming a logistical base for militant organisations, particularly factions of the Tehreek-e-Taliban Pakistan (TTP). As security operations intensified in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa and the tribal belt, militants sought anonymity in large urban centres. Pashtun-majority neighbourhoods such as Sohrab Goth, Manghopir and SITE became key sanctuaries and transit corridors where fighters, explosives and finances could be moved with relative ease.The turning point came on 8 June 2014, when ten militants launched an armed assault on Karachi’s Jinnah International Airport, using automatic weapons, grenades and a rocket launcher. The attack triggered an overnight battle that left at least 36 people dead, including all ten assailants. The incident severely embarrassed federal authorities and exposed vulnerabilities in Karachi’s security infrastructure. The scale of the attack underscored that the city’s violence was no longer just about gangs—it was also linked to national insurgency networks.In the aftermath, the state expanded its response. The federal and provincial governments granted Pakistan Rangers (Sindh) extensive policing and detention powers to target both militants and criminal networks. These operations aligned with ongoing national counterinsurgency campaigns, including Operation Zarb-e-Azb and later Operation Radd-ul-Fasaad, which aimed to dismantle militant networks and disrupt their finances and recruitment pipelines.In Karachi, this translated into a sustained, multi-year crackdown led by the Rangers. Tactical raids, mass arrests, prolonged detentions under special legal provisions and high-profile encounters became common features of urban policing. In Lyari, the result was a shrinking space for gangs to openly control territory. The Peoples’ Aman Committee and splinter factions still operated, but their public influence diminished as armed checkpoints, displays of heavy weaponry and enforced taxation became more difficult to sustain. Although pockets of violence persisted, the crackdown marked the beginning of the end of large, overt gang administrations in the city.One of the most high-profile casualties in the post-2014 security phase was SSP Chaudhry Aslam Khan, the police officer who had led major operations against both Lyari gangs and militant networks. On 9 January 2014, a suicide bomber drove an explosives-laden vehicle into Aslam’s convoy in Karachi, killing him and at least three others. The Tehreek-e-Taliban Pakistan (TTP) claimed responsibility, calling the attack revenge for police operations against its fighters and financiers. Aslam’s death was widely perceived as a serious setback to the city’s counter-terror and anti-gang efforts, though operations continued under other police officers and with greater reliance on Pakistan Rangers (Sindh).For Lyari’s armed groups, the most decisive blow came three years later. Acting on intelligence reports, Pakistan Rangers (Sindh) launched a pre-dawn raid on 2 February 2017 in Phool Patti Lane, Lyari, targeting Noor Muhammad, better known as “Baba Ladla.” According to Rangers’ statements, a gun battle lasting over 30 minutes ensued, during which gang members used automatic weapons and grenades. By the end of the raid, Rangers announced that Baba Ladla and two close associates had been killed.Listed for years among Pakistan’s “most wanted” criminals, Baba Ladla faced cases ranging from murder and extortion to armed attacks on police and suspected collaborations with extremist groups. His death effectively dismantled a key pillar of the Uzair-era structure, removing the most prominent operational commander who had challenged both rivals inside Lyari and the security forces sent to eliminate them.By the mid-2010s, as state pressure intensified and gang structures were fractured by successive operations, Uzair Jan Baloch left Pakistan. In December 2015, Interpol arrested him at Dubai International Airport, reportedly while he was travelling from Muscat. He was subsequently handed over to Pakistani authorities and brought back to Karachi.From 2016 onward, Uzair was charged in dozens of criminal cases, ranging from murder and attempted murder to extortion, kidnapping and terrorism. Many of these cases have since resulted in acquittals due to lack of evidence, hostile witnesses or procedural weaknesses—a pattern that has long characterised Karachi’s organised crime trials, where intimidation makes witness testimony difficult.In April 2017, a new dimension emerged when the Pakistan Army took custody of Uzair to try him under military law. He was accused of espionage and leaking sensitive information to a foreign intelligence agency, reportedly linked to Iran. In April 2020, a military court sentenced him to 12 years in prison on espionage charges, marking a significant shift in how the state officially characterized him—not merely as a gang leader, but as a potential national security threat.Pakistani officials and segments of local media have occasionally linked Uzair’s alleged intelligence connections to the controversial case of Kulbhushan Jadhav, the Indian national sentenced to death by a Pakistani military court in 2017. One strand of narrative suggests that Uzair’s alleged contacts in Iran overlapped with networks also linked to Jadhav. However, India has rejected Pakistan’s claims in the Jadhav case as coerced and unsubstantiated, and publicly verifiable evidence connecting Uzair directly to operational support for Jadhav remains limited.What is clearer is that, from the perspective of the Pakistani state, Uzair Baloch’s profile evolved from that of a gang leader embedded in local politics to an alleged cross-border security risk—reshaping the narrative around Lyari’s gangs and their significance.As violence worsened and Lyari began drawing national and even international scrutiny, the Pakistan Peoples Party (PPP) gradually shifted its stance on the Peoples’ Aman Committee (PAC). Between 2012 and 2013, amid pressure from rival parties, security agencies and media coverage, the PPP formally disowned the PAC, despite years of visible proximity.Senior party leaders later framed PAC figures as rogue actors or products of state neglect, arguing that they were not part of a deliberate political strategy. Critics, however—including journalists, residents and some researchers—contend that the PPP benefitted for years from PAC’s armed control of Lyari, only distancing itself once the political and reputational costs became unsustainable.This distancing reflected a broader shift: as the state redefined Lyari’s gangs from political intermediaries to security liabilities, political actors recalibrated their alliances. What had once been an informal partnership built on patronage and vote control became a liability in the age of counterterrorism and international scrutiny.Security indicators suggest that overt gang violence in Lyari has dropped sharply since the mid-2010s. Rangers-led operations, the removal or incarceration of key gang leaders such as Rehman, Uzair and Baba Ladla, and broader counter-terror campaigns have reduced the frequency of armed clashes and targeted killings in the area.The legacy of the Lyari gang war remains unfinished. For many families, the years of kidnappings, torture, blockades and forced recruitment left deep social and economic scars. Questions continue to surround extrajudicial killings, disappearances and the conduct of both the gangs and state agencies tasked with fighting them. Although large armed networks have been dismantled, traces of informal control and low-level criminality persist in new forms.At the same time, Lyari’s cultural and political identity is evolving again. The football grounds, community schools and cultural centres that once defined the neighbourhood are re-emerging, even as residents remain wary of new power brokers. In popular culture, recent portrayals such as Dhurandhar and other planned projects reflect an enduring public fascination with Lyari—its blurred boundaries between criminal groups, political actors and state security agencies, and the unanswered questions they leave behind.Seen in retrospect, the gang war was not merely the story of violent figures in a marginalised settlement. It grew out of structural inequality, weak state institutions and a political party’s reliance on armed intermediaries to protect its vote bank. As militancy and regional intelligence rivalries later intersected with local crime networks, a neighbourhood built from labour and sport became entangled in national security narratives.Lyari today is quieter, but its past continues to shape how residents understand politics, policing and protection. The names of Rehman Dakait, Uzair Baloch, Baba Ladla and Arshad Pappu remain part of local memory—sometimes condemned as criminals, sometimes recalled as flawed protectors, always as evidence of how quickly a working-class community can become a battleground when crime, politics and security policy converge.
Article Summary: Karachi’s Lyari has long been associated with a dual identity. To its residents, it is the ‘mother of Karachi’ – powered by dockworkers, truck drivers, boxers and footballers. To the rest of Pakistan, especially through the 1990s and 2000s, it came to signify something very different: a “mini Brazil” of football- obsessed alleys, heavily armed gangs, and extortion rackets. It is this layered, contradictory Lyari that Aditya Dhar's recent 'Dhurandhar' turns into cinema.

Article Title: IndiGo crisis triggers mass flight cancellations and soaring fares at Nagpur airport, only 5 takeoffs
Article Text: Nagpur: With 11 flights cancelled by evening, nearly half of the aircraft fleet operating from Nagpur was grounded due to the IndiGo Airlines crisis on Thursday. Fares of other carriers soared at the same time. Another carrier operating from Nagpur was charging Rs 22,000 for a ticket to Mumbai or Delhi for economy class — almost equal to business class rates. In some centres, it was as much as Rs 50,000 per person, with the earliest ticket not available before December 6. At the IndiGo Airlines counter, passengers only received uncertain replies on ticket availability in coming days. Only five flights took off from Nagpur on Thursday till 9pm.The cancelled flights included a plane bound for Pune from Kolkata, which was diverted to Nagpur midday, only to later scrap the journey. There were 162 persons aboard. This was not a typical emergency diversion from a technical snag or a medical emergency with a passenger, said sources. "The airlines simply said it was an operational reason," said a source.It was learnt there was no parking bay available at Pune airport, which was already full with cancelled flights.This led to the flight being diverted, and the journey was truncated, said a source in the airport management.By 9 pm, as many as 11 flights of IndiGo Airlines were cancelled, with many running inordinately delayed. The flights that were cancelled connected the city with Pune, Bengaluru, Mumbai, Delhi, Hyderabad and Goa. Most of these run on a to-and-fro basis, so even arrivals were affected. IndiGo is the largest player at the Nagpur airport, operating 22 flights. There are chances that more flights may be cancelled by midnight, said an employee. The signboard at the departure gate at 8:30pm displayed only the status of a lone flight."Don't ask for tickets for at least a week," said an executive at the booking counter. "Even we are not sure if there would be any available. Many flights that are running delayed are eventually being cancelled."An angry Devendra Singh and his friend Mukul Soni said they purchased a ticket, barely a couple of hours ago, only to find out that flights had been cancelled. "I purchased the ticket to Delhi right from the airline's portal at 7pm for a flight scheduled for 9pm. Why should they sell tickets if the flights were cancelled?" said Devendra. His friend, Mukul, also purchased a ticket around the same time from an aggregator's portal.The Wakharia family had to catch a flight to Tokyo from Delhi. Earlier, they had planned to fly to Delhi on Friday, but looking at the crisis, they preponed and booked tickets for Thursday, only for the plane to be cancelled. The family later booked a taxi to Delhi."The crisis also left the ground staff overstretched. We have to report at a given time, but there's no fixed schedule for return since two days. There's too much work, handling cancellations and rescheduling. If DGCA wants pilots to have fixed hours, why not the ground staff," asked one of them.
Article Summary: Nearly half of the aircraft fleet operating from Nagpur was grounded due to the IndiGo Airlines crisis on Thursday. Fares of other carriers soared at the same time. Another carrier was charging Rs 22,000 for a ticket to Mumbai or Delhi for economy class — almost equal to business class rates.

Article Title: Delhi Fuel Theft: Fill it, shut it, sell it: How a Delhi duo siphoned fuel from pipelines for 30 years; theft trail spans 4 states
Article Text:
AI Image

NEW DELHI: Over nearly three decades, Swarn Singh and his brother-in-law Dharmender, wanted across multiple states, honed a precise method of siphoning fuel from underground petroleum pipelines.What began as oil pilferage from tankers in the early 1990s evolved into a structured operation built around rented houses, concealed tunnels, improvised valves and night-time diversion of diesel. Their knowledge of a wide terrain and shifting techniques kept them a step ahead of police in at least three states until Delhi Police crime branch arrested them on Wednesday.On June 10, Jaipur police detected that HPCL MDPL pipeline near Dahmi Kalan had been tapped. They zeroed in on a rented house and found tools for digging, a bedroom tunnel and a galvanised pipe with valves for feeding diesel into tankers, a senior officer said. HPCL promptly removed the valves the two had fitted.A person from Assam who used to live in the house claimed the setup was created by "Swaran Singh Sardar". Swarn and Dharmender immediately went underground. "On Dec 3, acting on an input, the crime branch traced them to Vikaspuri and arrested them," the cop said.Both allegedly admitted they were involved in tapping pipelines in Jaipur and said they did the same in Kurukshetra, Bathinda, Jaipur, Paschim Vihar and Gurgaon, often using the same DIY method.Swarn's brush with crimes dates to the early 1990s when he worked as a tanker driver and would siphon fuel from the tankers. Dharmender, also a driver, later joined him.The two used to survey long stretches of pipelines and chose isolated points behind residential plots or on the outskirts of towns where pipeline markers were visible, but the movement of people was low. "To avoid suspicion, they would take a room or a shop on rent and run a small-time businesses like selling mineral water, while preparing to strike," DCP (crime) Harsh Indora said.On the premises, they used to shovel a tunnel towards a pipeline. The digging was done in phases over several days to avoid altering neighbours. Once they reached the pipeline, they fixed an improvised metal connection fitted with valves. A plastic hose would then run from the hidden tapping point to storage tanks or directly into a waiting tanker, which used to transport the fuel late at night.The tapping point was camouflaged, and only a handful of trusted associates were involved in the operations. The fuel was sold at a rate lower than the market price to transporters willing to buy "open diesel" or was sent to industrial buyers in small, hired vehicles. The two focused on the Jaipur route because of easy access to transporters and heavy movement of goods vehicles in the corridor.Swarn is linked to over a dozen cases in Delhi, Haryana, Rajasthan and Punjab. Charges against him include oil theft, cheating, damaging pipelines and violations under Petroleum & Minerals Pipelines Act. Dharmender has been named in cases of tapping pipelines in Jaipur and Punjab's Bathinda.
Article Summary: Swarn Singh and his brother-in-law Dharmender, wanted across multiple states, honed a precise method of siphoning fuel from underground petroleum pipelines. The two used to survey long stretches of pipelines and chose isolated points behind residential plots or on the outskirts of towns where pipeline markers were visible.

Article Title: Chennai weather: City sees heavy rain, relief expected from Friday; key points
Article Text:
Chennai rain

IMD Issues Red Alert as Cyclone Ditwah Approaches TN; Sri Lanka Deaths Exceed 80

Unseasonal, patchy showers caught commuters off guard, with many drenched due to sudden bursts of rain despite bright weather earlier in the morning.

North Chennai and Tiruvallur recorded continuous overnight rainfall, while the showers gradually shifted to southern parts of the city during the day.

Manali, Ennore and Wimco Nagar recorded over 20 cm of rainfall in 24 hours, making them the most affected localities.

A yellow alert was issued for multiple districts, including Chennai, Tiruvallur, Ranipet, Chengalpattu, Kancheepuram and the Nilgiris, due to the lingering impact of Cyclone Ditwah.

Waterlogging intensified across several city pockets, such as Vyasarpadi, Kodungaiyur, MKB Nagar and Mullai Nagar, prompting civic teams to pump out excess water into Buckingham and Captain canals.

Cyclone Ditwah’s aftereffects continued across Tamil Nadu, with three deaths reported in rain-related incidents, widespread crop damage in Nagapattinam, flooding near the Vedaranyeswara Temple, and infrastructure disruption in multiple districts.

Article Title: Thousands of Amazon employees send open letter to CEO Andy Jassy; say: We are the workers who develop, train, and use AI, so we have ...
Article Text:
Over 1,000 Amazon employees have penned an open letter to CEO Andy Jassy, expressing grave concerns about the company's rapid AI development. They argue this "warp-speed approach" prioritizes AI investments over climate commitments and human workforce well-being, potentially harming democracy, jobs, and the environment.

Amazon Launches Largest Layoff Drive Yet, Cutting 30,000 Corporate Positions to Boost Efficiency

Here's the complete open letter from Amazon 1000-plus employees:

Dear Andy Jassy and S-team,

In recent years, tech leaders have accelerated their race to build the most powerful AI first. “Sink or swim,” “AI is not going anywhere,” and “work with it or be replaced” have become mantras in workspaces at Amazon and beyond.

We, the undersigned Amazon employees, have serious concerns about this aggressive rollout during the global rise of authoritarianism and our most important years to reverse the climate crisis. We believe that the all-costs-justified, warp-speed approach to AI development will do staggering damage to democracy, to our jobs, and to the earth.

We’re the workers who develop, train, and use AI, so we have a responsibility to intervene. Here’s why we’re sounding the alarm:

Amazon is casting aside its climate goals to build AI. We have just a few years to stop disastrous levels of warming.

Yet despite committing to net zero carbon emissions by 2040, Amazon’s annual emissions have grown roughly 35% since 2019. The AI race is widening this gap. The company plans to spend $150 billion building new data centers for AI. Many of these will be in drought-stressed regions, where they will consume scarce water, or in locations where their energy demands will force utility companies to keep coal plants online or build new gas plants.

Amazon even killed legislation that would have required its data centers to use clean energy. Meanwhile, AWS is helping oil companies drill for more oil and gas.

Amazon is forcing us to use AI while investing in a future where it’s easier to discard us. Andy Jassy promised that soon Amazon will be full of AI tools and “agents,” and that he expects to employ fewer humans. He claims our (remaining) jobs will be “even more exciting and fun,” but here’s what we’re actually experiencing: higher expected output and shorter timelines, mandates to build AI tools for wasteful use cases, and massive investment in AI with little investment in career advancement.

Our logistics coworkers have been especially impacted by work speedups, surveillance, injuries and burnout. All this, while Amazon is attempting to declare the National Labor Relations Board, which protects workers’ rights, unconstitutional.

Amazon is helping build a more militarized surveillance state with fewer protections for ordinary people. Amazon, alongside Meta, Microsoft and Google lobbied to ban state regulation on AI for the next ten years; Trump financially disincentivized state regulatory action in his AI Action Plan. Trump demanded an end to “wokeness” in AI; Amazon has scaled back its commitments to DEI and offered the administration a 1 billion dollar coupon for AWS, with a DOGE staffer calling the deal “a foundational piece to help implement President Trump’s AI Action Plan.” The military wants AI technologies at top speed; Amazon has announced a collaboration with an autonomous weapons software company. Trump’s ICE Director wants to run mass deportation “like Prime, but with human beings”; Amazon, a major provider of cloud services to DHS and to Palantir, literally does power mass deportation. Amazon is expanding the surveillance state in other ways, too. It’s making Ring AI-first and re-introducing a tool for police to request footage; it’s using AI to surveil warehouse workers, and, of course, its own customers. Finally,

Jeff Bezos

owns The Washington Post, and has begun asserting more control over that publication; the other major AI players control mass information ecosystems like Instagram and X. If these collaborations continue, we will be ceding an unbelievable amount of power into the hands of an increasingly authoritarian government and a few companies willing to abandon any principles they claim to have in the race for AI dominance.

All of this is daunting, but none of it is inevitable. A better future is still very much within reach, but it requires us to get real about the costs of AI and the guardrails we need.

We demand Amazon leadership commit to the following:

No AI with dirty energy.

No more vague promises that “AI will solve the climate crisis.” Amazon must implement a public plan that includes: 1) powering all data centers with 100% additional, local renewable energy, 24/7, 2) ending custom AI solutions for oil & gas companies to drill more oil faster, and 3) publishing a detailed, science-backed glidepath for how it will meet its climate commitments.

No AI without employee voices.

We want ethical AI working groups of non-managers across the company that will have significant ownership over org-level goals and how or if AI should be used in their orgs, how or if AI-related layoffs or headcount freezes are implemented, and how to mitigate or minimize the collateral effects of AI use, such as environmental impact.

No AI for violence, surveillance, or mass deportation.

Amazon sells a huge range of products and services — from physical goods to digital infrastructure to films to medical services. It should not need to be helping surveil civilians in Gaza, collaborating with AI companies that specialize in drone warfare, or supporting a mass deportation machine.

The Amazon employees signing this letter believe in building a better world — not in building bunkers to fall back to. We want the promised gains from AI to give everyone more freedom to play and rest, to spend time with family and friends, to be moved by nature, to create, to feel safe being who we are.

This is an incredibly consequential moment in history. It’s time for us to step up and spark a conversation about the real benefits and costs of AI. Workers have guided Amazon to a better path before, and we can do it again. The choices we make now, for the planet, for its people and animals, matter more than ever. Let’s make ones we can be proud of.

Signed,

1,039 Amazon employees (and counting!)





Thousands of Amazon employees have signed an open letter issuing to CEO Andy Jassy . The letter warns the company about its 'rapid' move toward AI. Signed by more than 1,000 Amazon workers (and counting), the open letter calls out Amazon for pushing its AI investments at the expense of climate and human workforce. The letter’s supporters come from a wide array of roles at the company, including many software engineers, and even employees focused on building AI systems. "We believe that the all-costs-justified, warp-speed approach to AI development will do staggering damage to democracy, to our jobs, and to the earth,” the letter’s authors wrote. It adds, “We’re the workers who develop, train, and use AI, so we have a responsibility to intervene.”The open letter is reported to have been signed by Amazon workers anonymously, and comes almost a month after the ecommerce giant announced mass layoff plans as it increases adoption of AI in its operations. Among the signatories are employees in a range of positions, including engineers, product managers and warehouse associates. The letter argues that their employer is throwing out its climate promises in the scramble to win the AI race.Amazon has pledged to reach net-zero carbon emissions by 2040, pointing to efficiencies from electric delivery vehicles and reduced plastic packaging in its climate commitment.
Article Summary: Over 1,000 Amazon employees have penned an open letter to CEO Andy Jassy, expressing grave concerns about the company's rapid AI development. They argue this "warp-speed approach" prioritizes AI investments over climate commitments and human workforce well-being.

Article Title: Elon Musk's alarming prediction on Nikhil Kamath's podcast: "Working will be optional in less than..."
Article Text:
Source: YouTube (Podcast)

'US Benefited Immensely From Indians', Says Tesla CEO Elon Musk, Warns US Against Scrapping H-1B

How Elon Musk sees AI and robotics reshaping global industries





Elon Musk: A Different Conversation w/ Nikhil Kamath | Full Episode | People by WTF Ep. 16

Elon Musk’s prediction of AI-driven instant manufacturing





Elon Musk’s view of AI evolving beyond human well-being goals





Elon Musk’s vision of a future where ‘money becomes irrelevant’









Elon Musk has once again shared a striking prediction about the future of human labour. During a conversation on Nikhil Kamath’s People by WTF podcast, the Tesla and SpaceX chief suggested that the rapid evolution of artificial intelligence and robotics is pushing society towards a future where humans no longer need to work to survive. Musk’s view is rooted in the belief that machines will eventually handle all essential tasks, allowing people to approach work as a creative or recreational activity rather than an economic necessity.He expressed strong confidence that the world could reach this turning point within the next two decades. For Musk, this future is not a distant fantasy but a likely outcome of the accelerating technological breakthroughs unfolding today.Musk argued that the extraordinary pace of development in AI models, autonomous systems, and humanoid robots is already rapidly reshaping industries worldwide. According to him, the next phase of technological growth will create intelligent machines that can replicate or even surpass human capability in almost every domain, from manufacturing and logistics to healthcare, education, and creative services.He believes that this massive transition may occur much sooner than most people expect, possibly within ten to fifteen years. Musk compared future labour to home gardening. Just as people may choose to grow vegetables for enjoyment rather than necessity, he thinks future generations will increasingly engage in work for personal fulfilment, creativity, or social contribution rather than mere survival. The essential work that maintains society will be managed entirely by advanced automated systems that require minimal or no human oversight.A core part of Musk’s argument is that AI systems will eventually be able to create anything a person can imagine. His own AI company, xAI, along with its chatbot Grok, reflects his belief that increasingly capable generative systems will expand into physical production through robotics, automation, and smart manufacturing techniques. As these technologies combine, they could enable a world where scarcity becomes obsolete and resource distribution becomes more equitable. Musk visualises a future in which goods and services can be produced instantly and efficiently.He emphasised that the ability to turn ideas into tangible products without traditional labour inputs would fundamentally reshape economies, social structures, and the global workforce. Once technology reaches this stage, he thinks most constraints on human consumption and lifestyle will disappear, creating unprecedented opportunities for innovation, creativity, and human progress.Musk also explored a lesser-discussed aspect of hyper-advanced AI. He suggested that there may come a time when AI and robotics complete every possible task aimed at improving human well-being. After satisfying all imaginable human desires and demands, these systems could reach a saturation point where they no longer have meaningful human-centred tasks to perform.At that stage, Musk believes AI may begin working on activities that serve its own optimisation because the catalogue of tasks that benefit humanity is finite. This idea raises profound questions about the long-term relationship between humans and intelligent machines once human needs are no longer the defining force behind technological activity. Musk’s predictions extend far beyond the automation of work. At the US Saudi Investment Forum earlier this month, he stated that humanoid robots and AI systems have the potential to eliminate poverty. His argument relies on the assumption that when machines can produce goods for virtually no cost and at limitless volume, wealth becomes universal because essential resources are accessible to everyone.If machines can meet all human needs, the traditional economic struggle for income, resources, and opportunity would disappear. Musk envisions a world where every person benefits equally from the capabilities of intelligent robots that can generate abundance without relying on human labour.In his discussion with Kamath, Musk introduced an even more radical idea. He predicted that money might eventually lose its relevance. In his view, money exists primarily as a tool for allocating labour and determining the value of goods that require human effort to produce. If production becomes entirely automated and unlimited, the need for money as a mechanism for distribution fades.Musk suggested that in such a world, the primary form of value might shift towards power generation. Energy would become the foundational currency because machines require it to operate, create and sustain the systems that support human life. The economy would therefore revolve around energy capacity rather than labour or manufactured goods.
Article Summary: Elon Musk has shared a striking prediction about the future of human labour. The Tesla and SpaceX chief suggested that the rapid evolution of artificial intelligence and robotics is pushing society towards a future where humans no longer need to work to survive. Musk’s view is rooted in the belief that machines will eventually handle all essential tasks, allowing people to approach work as a creative or recreational activity. For Musk, this future is not a distant fantasy but a likely outcome of the accelerating technological breakthroughs unfolding today.
